subject: Re: [junit] A method for estimating number of junit test cases using Cyclomatic complexity
msgSnippet: ... How many days (or years) did it take to develop these 973 classes? ... Other notes: - 2 hours seems quite high for _each_ test method, but it depends on
messageBody:
> *Sample calculation
> Number of Classes = 973
> Average WMPC ~= 9 (normalized for getter and setter methods. I used
> Together ControlCenter->Metrics for all these measures)
>
> Total effort for writing Junit tests = (9 * 973) * 2 hrs = 17, 514 hours
> = 2189 Person Days.

How many days (or years) did it take to develop these 973 classes?

> (*huh..hmm*. Let the beatings begin. I can't adequaltely express in
> words my manager's bewildered expression on seeing this number. But,
> that's another story.)

Other notes:
- 2 hours seems quite high for _each_ test method, but it depends on the
complexity of the classes
- why not starting from the top-most class? Develop tests for this
class and as bug are found, extend your unit/regression suite
- did the developers write JUnit tests that you can reuse?

-Vladimir

--
Vladimir R. Bossicard
www.bossicard.com
